content:
Hey guys, I'm not sure users understand what is the idle status mean for observers. The fact that @Alya Abbott couldn't clearly answer that is the sign of something isn't straightforward.
Like you are idle and what should I do with that? Is it "he can be online any minute?" "he can be offline any minute?"

The current half filled circle icon is grabbing to much attention: image.png
And I want to fix that, but I don't want to fight with you all in a long conversations about importance of the status which people don't understand clearly :stuck_out_tongue_wink:. So here is the suggestion: image.png

You ask me "Vlad but it is not accesible for people with color perception deviations, how can we solve this problem?". And my answer would be "It is accesible, here are color blind filters variations:"
Frame-41.png
@Alya Abbott any feedback?
Looks great
First row of this also looks good https://chat.zulip.org/user_uploads/2/4f/M1nKlY7csPUJsb66Lh3LWf37/Frame-41.png
I'm open to it. :) I also kicked off #general > presence information in case we can figure out how to make the meanings of the presence states more consistent.
I'm not sure the problem is the half-filled circle; I'd say the orange color (which is a "warning" color direction) is what seems to grab attention in my mind.
So I'd also want to look at versions where the idle color is e.g. just a half-filled circle in a lighter green.
The black circles around the "available" status icons in the currently deployed version look really weird to me. Are those intentional? @Steve Howell (showell)

I don't think so:

Steve Howell (showell) said:

Hrm, I am seeing dark borders on the normal green circles. That's not intentional.
see #general > presence information
I believe we've deployed an updated version.

What do folks think? I feel like I'd appreciate some kind of color difference, whether it's a more muted version of the green/orange we had previously, or (perhaps) darker vs. lighter green.

One thing that's a bit awkward about the regular vs. lighter green idea is that we also have the fading behavior in the right sidebar. We plan to get rid of it in #20072, but it's there for now.
A color difference would be nice.

fwiw: I really dislike the green half circles. You could say that I'm just being resistant to change but I would disagree.
There's a bunch of colors suggested above, I'd prefer any of them.
I'm in the process of cleaning up #20949 so that we can merge some code cleanup before actually messing with the colors.

One little tip for anybody who wants to play around with idle circles in their dev environment (whether for formatting or other reasons) is to use this little do-not-merge patch on top of my PR (and hopefully soon on top of main):

--- a/static/js/buddy_data.js
+++ b/static/js/buddy_data.js
@@ -46,7 +46,7 @@ export function get_user_circle_class(user_id) {
         case "away_me":
             return "user_circle_empty_line";
         default:
-            return "user_circle_empty";
+            return "user_circle_idle";
     }
 }

I now have this single line of CSS in my local branch (soon to be pushed) that lets me play with the colors:

$idle_color: hsl(29, 84%, 51%);
BTW I agree with the feedback on the green/half-green experiment. I kinda like the monochrome feel, but I agree that the states look too similar now.

Here are the colors on main:

image.png

I think reducing the saturation from 84% to 60% is a pretty immediate improvement:

image.png

Then I wanted to tweak hue a bit:

  • we have already vetoed the shade of green in the active circles
  • hues between orange and green just tend to be kinda ugly (e.g. "puke green")
  • hues in the blue/purple range feel too active to me, especially with our blue buttons and general blue branding

So my best attempt was to move from orange toward a more pure red...

Here is what moving the hue from 29 -> 15 looks like:

image.png
(I should state explicitly that I am super wary of messing with the active green color next to aaron's name, since our users have almost never complained about it. But that's just my opinion.)

The best hue I could find in the pink/purple range was 335:

image.png
I like that shade, but it seems to clash too much with the green.
Ok #20949 is now up to date. I am hoping Alya Abbott can play around with it a bit on Monday.
see #general > ✔ presence information for some other feedback

Here's the executive summary of my proposal:

  • improve the code
  • keep the idle circles half-white (or half-dark in dark theme)
  • tweak the orange from hsl(29, 84%, 51%) to hsl(15, 60%, 51%)

So we see what @Tim Abbott wanted to see. I think its better than yellow, but half circles grabs attention and the green is very saturated.
I thought about the design I suggested earlier?

So here is the improved suggestion from me.
Idle status is something between Online (green) and offline (hallow with grey stroke). So here is the version:
smaller-dots.png

Circle size is also smaller: 8px, in case of grey outline, which is 2px, the circle size is 6px

  • Online Green color is #73BF88
  • Idle color is #D3CFAB
  • offline stroke color is #A8A8A8
Color Blind Filters:

Vlad Korobov said:

So we see what Tim Abbott wanted to see.

We didn't really disprove Tim's hypothesis, where he basically stated that the main problem with the status quo might simply be that the orange color is too loud. We instead disproved my stronger hypothesis, which is that we didn't even need a different color here. The results of the experiment are that people clearly value contrasting colors.

Vlad Korobov said:

Circle size is also smaller: 8px, in case of grey outline, which is 2px, the circle size is 6px

  • Online Green color is #73BF88
  • Idle color is #D3CFAB
  • offline stroke color is #A8A8A8

I am gonna try to add that to my PR. If nothing else, I can clean up the underlying code a bit more.

Here's a bit more code cleanup:

$ git diff
diff --git a/static/styles/user_circles.css b/static/styles/user_circles.css
index ade93e3cae..d31fab91e6 100644
--- a/static/styles/user_circles.css
+++ b/static/styles/user_circles.css
@@ -1,3 +1,4 @@
+$active_color: hsl(106, 74%, 44%);
 $idle_color: hsl(29, 84%, 51%);

 .user_circle_green,
@@ -12,8 +13,8 @@ $idle_color: hsl(29, 84%, 51%);
 }

 .user_circle_green {
-    background-color: hsl(106, 74%, 44%);
-    border-color: hsl(106, 74%, 44%);
+    background-color: $active_color;
+    border-color: $active_color;
 }

@Vlad Korobov Does this look about right?

image.png
image.png

diff --git a/static/styles/user_circles.css b/static/styles/user_circles.css
index 3705336811..45e78c368d 100644
--- a/static/styles/user_circles.css
+++ b/static/styles/user_circles.css
@@ -1,5 +1,6 @@
-$active_color: hsl(106, 74%, 44%);
-$idle_color: hsl(15, 60%, 51%);
+$active_color: hsl(137, 37%, 60%);
+$idle_color: hsl(54, 31%, 75%);
+$empty_border_color: hsl(0, 0%, 66%);

 .user_circle_green,
 .user_circle_idle,
@@ -36,11 +37,11 @@ $idle_color: hsl(15, 60%, 51%);

 .user_circle_empty {
     background-color: none;
-    border-color: hsl(0, 0%, 50%);
+    border-color: $empty_border_color;
 }

 .user_circle_empty_line {
-    border-color: hsl(0, 0%, 50%);
+    border-color: $empty_border_color;
Ok, I pushed a new version of #20949.
On your screen the Green is bigger than others, can we make it the same size… looks like we need to remove border from green
Oh, you want all the circles smaller?
No… on your image the green is about 1px bigger in radius than idle and offline
I want the green to be the same size as idle
But hey we can try the way you did it too
Like “green is a bit more important than anything else”

Vlad Korobov said:

Like “green is a bit more important than anything else”

Yeah, let's try it out. I misunderstood your intentions here, but I do think there's some logic in having the active circles stand out for something other than color, even though the contrast should be fine for even color-vision-impaired folks.
Having tried out the PR on dev, I'm not sure how I feel about the bigger green circles, but I'm game to try out on CZO.
Yeah, that is questionable

I am hoping to try out this instead:

https://github.com/zulip/zulip/pull/20949#issuecomment-1028012889
Interesting approach

It looks like there's a version of this deployed here now that's a green filled circle for active, and a slightly smaller pale filled circle for idle:
image.png

That distinction looks way too subtle to me. I feel like I have to look twice to even be sure there is a distinction, and a third time to be sure exactly where in the list it is.
The alignment on the circles looks off to me (too low with respect to the text).
I didn’t suggest to make variable size but Greg is expressing confusion with something. So what is the issue? Its hard to distinguish colors between online and semi online status?
From my understanding the nature of distinction is very fuzzy
I suspect that green-full-circle vs yellow-slightly-smaller-circle also won't pass muster with red-green colorblind folks.
Alex there was a test for color blindness
we didn’t test/design dark version

Steve Howell (showell) said:

Vlad Korobov said:

So we see what Tim Abbott wanted to see.

We didn't really disprove Tim's hypothesis, where he basically stated that the main problem with the status quo might simply be that the orange color is too loud. We instead disproved my stronger hypothesis, which is that we didn't even need a different color here. The results of the experiment are that people clearly value contrasting colors.

Yeah, my hypothesis was that we'd do the half-circles with a lighter shade of green, not that we use the same green. I agree with the same green it didn't look good. It's possible that a lighter green with half-circles also wouldn't work, but we haven't yet checked.

On the colorblindness point, I do wonder whether there's an argument that we should aim for it to be both (A) have it work for colorblind folks and (B) appear to do so. I'm not sure whether many folks evaluating software check for that issue who aren't themselves colorblind.
I don’t understand guys why its so important to have idle status. How is it affecting users?
Personally, I find idle users to be misleading and tend to ignore them.

I am also in the camp that the idle status is more distracting than helpful.

I really like the colors that we tried out yesterday.
Yeah, the colors are nice.
I don't know about the half-circle question, but I'm definitely appreciating the muted colors.
Greg pointed out (correctly, IMO) that the colors don’t work at all in dark mode. For those of you who like these colors, can you clarify whether you’re in light mode or dark mode?
Light mode; agreed that we should do something different in dark mode.
Light mode
@Anders Kaseorg I made them for white BG. I've never even checked them on Dark theme, and I didn't know we are jumping that quick to implementation.
Guys its a first time in last 2 days I'm checking the desktop version. I think idle colors are working great. I would still suggest to have size as in idle for all three...
For some reason for the offline status circle could be skewed like this image.png
Here is a quick suggestion for colors for the dark theme: image.png

Idle status color for the dark theme is #807936
Text labels for names color is #CDCDCD
status circle size should be 8x8

Just for my understanding, is it generally easier to apply these kinds of changes to both light mode and dark mode at once, rather than just doing one mode if we haven't had a chance to think about the other one yet?
We can easily do both simultaneously.
I guess my question is -- is it also easy to do just one, or no?
I'm in light mode but I don't like these colors a whole lot. It's probably just resistance to change.
We can do an experiment that specifically changes just one of the modes, if that is helpful for collecting feedback.
On the main branch we use the same presence colors in both modes, but it’s only four lines of code for us to split out colors for dark mode.

Correction about colors: image.png
I tuned green too.
Online status color for the dark theme is #46B966
Idle status color for the dark theme is #807936
Text labels for names color is #CDCDCD

With a current blue background colors got to be a bit stronger. Once we design a dark theme, we might change that.
Can you tweak the idle color a bit? It has a little resemblance to what I call “puke green”.
that is how it works for accesibility, puke is due to it less green. And puke color has a very wide range. Think about turtle
color blind people on average see more puke colors
We can try it out. Color perception is very subjective.

I probably shouldn’t even weigh in on dark mode. I really like the light mode color choices you made. I like the overall look of our dark theme, but my eyes struggle with it due to some of the too-similar colors.

Steve the color of idle is more algorithmic rather than tasteful. If you want we could do that exercise during the meeting. But I suggest to wait until we are going to design dark theme, where the general intention is to reduce the vibrance of the dark blue, after that it would be possible to tune other colors. Current dark theme bg color puts more limitations.
Fair enough. I think our only negative feedback on light mode colors came from @Yash RE. I am curious if a little more time with the new colors changed his opinion.
Even setting aside alignment quirks, I view my 8px/7px/6px experiment as negative.
I would like, however, to preserve some kind of visual distinction that isn’t color-based.

I am curious if a little more time with the new colors changed his opinion.

Not yet but I was also away from CZO most of the day.
Is there anything we can do better than half circles?

I'm not sure we should try super hard to make idle status super different from online by form. These 2 status are not that different. Offline vs Online should be different and it is also done by a color, which perceived as a shape: hallow circle vs filled circle.
The two statuses are very different to me.
There's a pretty big difference between knowing that somebody is actually online vs. they didn't close the tab.
I would infer from the feedback that we received from both Greg and Anders that they value being able to distinguish the two states.
Do you mean to say "hollow"?
yes... sorry

Greg and Anders that they value being able to distinguish the two states

I didn't say they shouldn't be distinguished. The question is amount of contrast. I don't think that online and idle are that different that we need to emphasize that with shape+color+size. I think one factor should be enough.
Well, I would defend our original choice of half-hollow circles for the idle status.
Ok, how are we going to decide this battle of taste? Democracy, enlightened despotism, some kind of quorum, role based trust?

Should I defend every decide decision by the UX research with statistical significant unbiased number of respondents?
Should we use the "facebook's" rollout and measure product metric approach?
Should I personally do a validation with every person with a veto power?
Jokes aside guys I think we should clarify the rules of the game a bit, because I can't be effective player in the game I don't understand

It's pretty simple. We're an anarcho-syndicalist commune. We take it in turns to act as a sort of executive officer for the week.

But all the decision of that officer have to be ratified at a special biweekly meeting. By a simple majority in the case of purely internal affairs, but by a two-thirds majority in the case of more...

I'm not sure I understood the strikethrough text.
I desire formalization of the game, so I understand how to approach things.
(It's a Monty Python reference.)

The ultimate decisions get made by Tim. I don't understand the full rules of the game, and the rules are probably evolving.

The purpose of czo experiments is to collect some immediate feedback on possible ideas before rolling anything out to a broader audience.

online and idle

Is idle what happens when somebody leaves their computer on overnight? Because that seems pretty different from online.
Yep, basically that's what idle means.

Steve Howell (showell) said:

Yep, basically that's what idle means.

Is it actually? Isn't that I could be switching tabs and be online in 5 minutes?
You can go into idle status within 5 minutes or so, but you can stay in idle status for quite long.

The ultimate decisions get made by Tim

Good start

I don't understand the full rules of the game

That is not good.

the rules are probably evolving

Sure. I just want to know on which version I'm now and when the new version is in effect.

some immediate feedback on possible ideas

We should clarify how such feedback is treated. Which voices mean what.

before rolling anything out to a broader audience

I think before rolling out there is some kind of stabilization period and other important checkmarks should be done.

Steve Howell (showell) said:

You can go into idle status within 5 minutes or so, but you can stay in idle status for quite long.

so idle status is actually a huge fuzzy range between online and offline?
https://chat.zulip.org/help/status-and-availability#about-availability
@Steve Howell (showell) do you honestly think that the documentation link you've posted has opened my eyes on the problem of confusing perception of the idle status?
Not active is a very broad range

Vlad Korobov said:

Steve Howell (showell) do you honestly think that the documentation link you've posted has opened my eyes on the problem of confusing perception of the idle status?

I have no idea how it changed your perception. This is a public stream, so you're not the only audience for the link.

Vlad Korobov said:

before rolling anything out to a broader audience

I think before rolling out there is some kind of stabilization period and other important checkmarks should be done.

One of the checkmarks is to try out a few things on czo, which has a much smaller audience than Zulip Cloud.

offline is not a range, is almost a fact, same thing with online.
Should we be able to distinguish them -sure. How vital is this visual distinguishment?
Are we air traffic controllers here?
My judgement is color should be enough and I described my logic and showed examples and tested how it will be perceived for color blind people.
Somebody implemented that to try, but the trying process isn't about what exactly in the design and the dark theme isn't worked out.
I think its working better than same color half circle. And I think its working better than different color half circle.
Can I be wrong? Sure. But how should we validate that?
Should just 1-2-4-N people to disagree/complain/struggle to roll it back? Are they biased? Are they design experts? Are they super representative?
I just need to know that and I will work accordingly.

Anyway, I think "active" and "idle" are very different. Active means "yeah, they'll probably see a message". Idle means "maybe they were aronud five minutes ago, maybe they've been gone for eight hours and won't be back for another eight". (Maybe this is just my style of using Zulip, but I think for me "idle" is probably more like "offline" than like "active".)

Honestly I'm surprised the "active" cutoff is only 140 seconds. Three minutes vs eight hours seems like a big difference -- much bigger than one second vs three minutes. Though I guess there's some sort of mouseover info that might useful for drilling down more.

(Though... I guess if I think of "active" as "they're actively chatting and likely to reply in a few minutes" rather than "they're at their computer and will probably see a notification or switch tabs in the next hour" it makes more sense.)
(I'll note that while I use the webapp a lot for work, my CZO usage is a third-party terminal client, so I don't see the UX experiments much.)

Interesting perspective Alex. I personally don’t care about status at all and its not affecting what/when/to whom I write. Because person might not read my message when they are online or might just don’t respond after reading it.
Online for me - you have higher chances to get response faster. Offline is - you have fewer chances to get response in the next 12 hours.
Idle for me is the confusion to which bucket should I put the person. For now I’m putting idle people to online, but decreasing my speed expectation.

(I'm a little confused about the downside of the current color but a half circle? It doesn't seem like it should be hard or disruptive, so if it's useful for people for some reason it seems reasonable to do?)

The half-circle has been in place since 2014. Folks like Greg/Aman/Yash/Alya/Anders/me who have been on the project for a long time are gonna have some personal biases, but we are also good proxies for what users want. We have heard every user complaint. We have seen various iterations of design from other professional designers. Even when we haven't gotten first hand feedback, we've had close proximity to product managers who tell us about what customers want.
Did I understand correctly that I should optimize design to have 7 OKs (a particular list of people, including Tim) since they are good proxies of what users want?
No, everything so far is just a data point. No decisions have been made yet.
Are you talking about decision of the process or decision about a particular color/shape of idle status?
The latter
fwiw: I like these colors significantly more than the green half circle.

@Palash Raghuwanshi said in #feedback:

Just a general appreciation :- I noticed the new colors of online status of users in right sidebar, and I think they look really good in the dark theme, soothing on the eye, good work!

It's worth noting that the presence circles also show up in the Private Messages section, which has a background color. I think they look fine in light theme, and I wonder if the background color here is gonna go away as the part of the larger re-design. For now it's just something to keep in the back of our minds:

image.png
Thanks for that pointing out that interaction; it may not be important, but is definitely worth noting.
Also: We're back to having the current main implementation running on chat.zulip.org for now, so we can remember how things are now.

Vlad Korobov said:

smaller-dots.png

s
@Vlad Korobov I am really curious as to you are getting the rest of the UI on the webapp? It looks so good, much better than the current design. Are you using some custom css/extension?
@Abhigyan Khaund this is an ongoing redesign project; see #design > UI redesign for some context.
So the screenshots are for making this specific change on top of other details present the current prototype.
(It's not possible to run right now, but the hope is we'll move Zulip to a design along these lines for everyone)
For anyone wondering about the precise details of what exactly being "idle" means, you can take a look at #general > ✔ presence information .
@Abhigyan Khaund we are in the process of designing the new look of Zulip
Thanks for the information Tim and Vlad. These design choices definitely makes it look more modern and better while keeping the aesthetics of Zulip. A move in good design direction!

I'm proposing to decrease attention to "away" / "online" people by using faint grey circle instead of the hollow circle, which grabs attention:
image.png image.png
Here you can see it in your browser https://zulip-compose.vladkorobov.repl.co/
This topic was moved here from #design > UI redesign: user status circle by Alya Abbott.

@_Notification Bot|5 said:

This topic was moved here from #design > UI redesign: user status circle by Alya Abbott.

I think we already talked about changing this notice -- I just moved the last 2 messages. :)

It's not easy to tell from the thread above why we didn't move forward with this change previously, and I don't recall the details.

@Vlad Korobov , if the suggested colors are not the same as the version a few months ago, could you do the colorblindness test again, like you did here?

Right, here is it. I made the online a bit darker in the light theme and I made idle a bit darker in the dark theme.
image.png
image.png

I also updated the colors in the example https://zulip-compose.vladkorobov.repl.co/

The main idea is that offline is consistent with other colors and doesn't attract much attention.
I apologize for chiming in this late into this conversation, but rather than faint grey circle for idle users, could no circle be more appropriate?
(could also help with designing for the colorblindness requirement mentioned earlier)
@shrizza I'm not sure what are you suggesting. The idea of not having a circle is interesting, I thought about it.
And faint grey circle is almost not circle. It is just a bit weird in some places when there is emptiness instead of an icon.
The idle colors on light theme are too light from my perspective, almost offline; though dark seems better.
I tend to agree the grey color looks to be too faint in both light and dark themes; we need it to have enough contrast that it can't be confused for the presence dot being missing.
But I'm glad we're working on this; the current presence dot styling feels to me like it's a bit of a wart.

Vlad Korobov said:

Right, here is it. I made the online a bit darker in the light theme and I made idle a bit darker in the dark theme.
image.png
image.png

I guess the difference between idle and offline looks quite subtle in the last 2 columns of the light theme table.
last 2 columns are people who have no color vision at all. For these cases there are hight contrast themes, we could do such in future

Neil Pilgrim (neiljp) said:

The idle colors on light theme are too light from my perspective, almost offline; though dark seems better.

Similar for me — in the light-theme image, the yellow for idle looks close enough to the gray for offline that I feel like it'd be easy to mistake them for each other short of looking carefully.

Updated.
Was: image.png
Now: image.png

I think that works for me!

Would want to do the color-vision check again, naturally.
image.png
I guess the colors in the 5th column aren't very distinct on this one.
We can’t satisfy all the people with colors
There are specific cases for those
Like hight contrast themes
There are people with low vision in general.

Vlad Korobov said:

We can’t satisfy all the people with colors

True. This is a major reason why the existing design doesn't rely purely on color for this information.
Are you saying that we should keep the current design of the user statuses?
I guess I we have different perception of importance / annoyance of status indicators

1% of people with this particular color blindness probably not allowed to drive a car, but we going to make 99% of zulip users be aware of that fact because we made a annoying online/away/offline icon?
Hight contrast theme is the better way to address such needs
If we truly care lets get all of those people as testers and will verify any design mock with them.
Do we have stats on how common the conditions are for each column?

Yeah, that'd be helpful information. I should mention that we do have an abortive "high contrast mode" setting that currently does absolutely nothing and thus is only visible in the development environment, so if data suggests the cases where this revision would be problematic are common enough, we can potentially unhide that setting and have the only thing it does (for now) be an adjustment here.

(I know we have gotten praise from some users who care about accessibility for the current UI, but I have no specific reason to believe it's because it actually was necessary for their personal experience, vs. just because seeing it made them feel like we care about accessibility.)

How about just dividing the various categories of status with the appropriate status name and a light divider line? Kind of like what's already there for the stream categories ("Pinned", "Active", etc). This could loosen the color/contrast requirement at least in the context of the userlist.
I think our plans for the sidebar do include that. But we display these in other places in the app as well, and they need to be readable there too.

Do we have stats on how common the conditions are for each column?

The problematic case was Protanopia vision which is the worse case of Protanomaly vision:
image.png

The 8% of colour blind men with inherited colour blindness can be divided approximately into 1% deuteranopes, 1% protanopes, 1% protanomalous and 5% deuteranomalous. Approximately half of colour blind people will have a mild anomalous deficiency, the other 50% have moderate or severe anomalous conditions.

That is why I said about 1%. Idle status is not something that all people require in all chat apps, usually there are just 2.

From my perspective the choose here is to either use shape, increase contrast of lightnes or drop 3 circles and have just 2. For example no circle for offline users - which is ok.
Here is example of darker green:
image.png

To be hones I would love to try "no circle for offline users" because there are just 2 cases: no circle over the userpic and not circle on the left side of the userpic

I do think we have such problems for 1% of people in multiple places. And "high contrast mode" or "black and white" theme could be a solution. I just don't want to address it only for status circles and I don't understand why is everybody so stressed about them
Here is the higher contrast in dark theme image.png
